articles.headline: Shootings Further Divide a Nation Torn Over Race
articles.snippet: This week’s convulsive events have prompted anguished pleas for unity and echoes of the protests and divisions of the late 1960s and early ’70s.
articles.abstract: This week’s convulsive events have prompted anguished pleas for unity and echoes of the protests and divisions of the late 1960s and early ’70s.
articles.lead_paragraph: First came the cellphone video of an African-American man being fatally shot by a Louisiana police officer, and the astonishing live feed of a Minnesota woman narrating the police killing of her African-American boyfriend during a traffic stop. Then came the horrific live television coverage of police officers being gunned down by a sniper at a march protesting the police shootings.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Gretchen Carlson Suit Aims at Retaliation Over Discrimination
articles.snippet: The suit is following a trend so pronounced that it has sometimes displaced attempts to remedy the discriminatory treatment itself.
articles.abstract: The suit is following a trend so pronounced that it has sometimes displaced attempts to remedy the discriminatory treatment itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the complaint that Gretchen Carlson, the former Fox News anchor, filed this week against Roger Ailes, the network’s chairman, one thing stands out above all: the overtness of the sexual harassment that Ms. Carlson says she endured.

articles.headline: Dallas Police Chief David Brown, a Reformer, Becomes Face of Nation’s Shock
articles.snippet: As Chief Brown sorted through a jumble of reports, some of them wrong, publicly narrating the standoff between his officers and the gunman, he also offered simple, emotional words.
articles.abstract: As Chief Brown sorted through a jumble of reports, some of them wrong, publicly narrating the standoff between his officers and the gunman, he also offered simple, emotional words.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the killings in Dallas, David O. Brown, the city’s police chief, became the face of the nation’s shock.

articles.headline: Obama’s Delicate Balance on Issue of Race and Policing
articles.snippet: The president delivered a call for racial justice after two black men were killed by the police, only to face the cameras hours later to denounce the killings of five officers.
articles.abstract: The president delivered a call for racial justice after two black men were killed by the police, only to face the cameras hours later to denounce the killings of five officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — As Air Force One headed for Europe on Thursday afternoon, President Obama holed up in the plane’s office editing a Facebook post meant to express his anguish at two deadly shootings by police officers. Given what had happened, he told his aides, he didn’t think it was enough.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Steinway’s Grand Ambitions for Its Pianos in China
articles.snippet: To breathe new life into its sales, the celebrated piano maker is promoting its instruments to China’s growing middle class both as a status symbol and an investment.
articles.abstract: To breathe new life into its sales, the celebrated piano maker is promoting its instruments to China’s growing middle class both as a status symbol and an investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: NINGBO, China — Dozens of girls in tiaras and boys in tuxedos who dreamed of becoming China’s next musical sensation stared at the beast onstage. At nine feet long and nearly 1,000 pounds, with a steely black sheen and a price of more than $200,000, the Steinway & Sons D-274 concert grand piano seemed designed to intimidate.

articles.headline: Micah Johnson, Gunman in Dallas, Honed Military Skills to a Deadly Conclusion
articles.snippet: Mr. Johnson, who killed five police officers, wrote about a combat tactic known as “shoot and move” and rehearsed in his backyard, officials said.
articles.abstract: Mr. Johnson, who killed five police officers, wrote about a combat tactic known as “shoot and move” and rehearsed in his backyard, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARLAND, Tex. — There was a time when he was known as a well-mannered young man — a regular at his church and a pleasant presence on a tree-lined, suburban, multicultural street in a neighborhood called Camelot. He grew up to serve his country in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Manny Fernandez and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Redfin Shies Away From the Typical Start-Up’s Gig Economy
articles.snippet: Redfin, a Seattle company that considers itself a real estate and tech company, has challenged the conventions of both by hiring full-time agents.
articles.abstract: Redfin, a Seattle company that considers itself a real estate and tech company, has challenged the conventions of both by hiring full-time agents.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Glenn Kelman became the chief executive of his online real estate start-up, he defied the tech industry’s conventional wisdom about how to grow.

articles.headline: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Struggle to Be Unifying Voice for Nation
articles.snippet: The violence of the past week cried out more for a unifying candidate and revealed how hard it is for Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton to become that person.
articles.abstract: The violence of the past week cried out more for a unifying candidate and revealed how hard it is for Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton to become that person.
articles.lead_paragraph: No moment in the 2016 presidential campaign has cried out more for a unifying candidate than the police shootings of two black men last week and the ensuing national uproar, followed by the shocking sniper ambush that killed five police officers in Dallas.

articles.headline: A Struggle for Common Ground, Amid Fears of a National Fracture
articles.snippet: People in interviews across the United States said the nation increasingly felt mired in bloodshed and blame, and was fracturing along racial and ideological lines.
articles.abstract: People in interviews across the United States said the nation increasingly felt mired in bloodshed and blame, and was fracturing along racial and ideological lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long after her two sons were in bed, Shanel Berry kept vigil in front of the television at her home in Waterloo, Iowa, watching the week’s horror unfurl and obsessing over a single question: Was the gunman who killed five Dallas police officers black?
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Nikole Hannah-Jones

articles.headline: Black Lives Matter Was Gaining Ground. Then a Sniper Opened Fire.
articles.snippet: The group faces perhaps the biggest crisis in its short history, as it scrambles to distance itself from the Dallas gunman and tries to rebut a chorus of detractors.
articles.abstract: The group faces perhaps the biggest crisis in its short history, as it scrambles to distance itself from the Dallas gunman and tries to rebut a chorus of detractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: It felt like a watershed moment for a scattered and still-young civil rights movement.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Donald Trump Keeps Distance in G.O.P. Platform Fight on Gay Rights
articles.snippet: A contentious debate between conservatives and moderates has left Mr. Trump mainly on the sidelines, but offering assurances to both sides.
articles.abstract: A contentious debate between conservatives and moderates has left Mr. Trump mainly on the sidelines, but offering assurances to both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Same-sex marriage and transgender rights are emerging as points of serious strain between social conservatives and moderates who are trying to shape the Republican platform, reviving a festering cultural dispute as thousands of party activists and delegates prepare for their convention.

articles.headline: Dallas Gunman Had Plans for Wider Attack, Police Say
articles.snippet: Micah Johnson had practiced explosive detonations, the city’s police chief said, providing new details of how Mr. Johnson sang, laughed and taunted officers during negotiations.
articles.abstract: Micah Johnson had practiced explosive detonations, the city’s police chief said, providing new details of how Mr. Johnson sang, laughed and taunted officers during negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The gunman who killed five police officers in Dallas had enough bomb-making materials in his home to lead the authorities to believe he was planning a larger attack, the city’s police chief said on Sunday. He provided new details of how, during two hours of negotiations, the gunman sang, laughed and asked how many officers he had killed before he was killed by a bomb-equipped robot.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: Forget Beanbag Chairs. Amazon Is Giving Its Workers Treehouses.
articles.snippet: Amazon is building a complex at its Seattle headquarters where employees can sit by a creek, walk on suspension bridges and brainstorm in the boughs.
articles.abstract: Amazon is building a complex at its Seattle headquarters where employees can sit by a creek, walk on suspension bridges and brainstorm in the boughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Just off a remote stretch of road here, near wineries, horse stables and farms, Amazon is secretly growing something, but it’s not what Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, calls the “tiny seeds” that could become the company’s next big businesses.

articles.headline: A New Disney Princesa Carries Responsibilities Beyond Her Kingdom
articles.snippet: Disney has created its first Latina princess, Elena, who will have her debut on the Disney Channel this month.
articles.abstract: Disney has created its first Latina princess, Elena, who will have her debut on the Disney Channel this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “It was finally my time.”

articles.headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, No Fan of Donald Trump, Critiques Latest Term
articles.snippet: Justice Ginsburg took stock of a tumultuous term for the Supreme Court after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia and gave her thoughts about a Trump presidency.
articles.abstract: Justice Ginsburg took stock of a tumultuous term for the Supreme Court after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia and gave her thoughts about a Trump presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unless they have a book to sell, Supreme Court justices rarely give interviews. Even then, they diligently avoid political topics. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg takes a different approach.

articles.headline: What Trump and the G.O.P. Can Agree On: Tax Cuts for the Rich
articles.snippet: The tax plan shepherded by House Speaker Paul Ryan would fundamentally change the system, but both plans reduce taxes on capital gains and high incomes.
articles.abstract: The tax plan shepherded by House Speaker Paul Ryan would fundamentally change the system, but both plans reduce taxes on capital gains and high incomes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In some important ways, the House Republicans’ new plan to overhaul the tax code has more in common with proposals from the candidates who lost their party’s presidential nomination than those from Donald J. Trump, the one poised to win it.

articles.headline: As Online Video Surges, Publishers Turn to Automation
articles.snippet: Tronc, the rebranded Tribune Publishing, wants to offer 2,000 videos a day, up from about 200 now, and hands-off video production is central to that aim.
articles.abstract: Tronc, the rebranded Tribune Publishing, wants to offer 2,000 videos a day, up from about 200 now, and hands-off video production is central to that aim.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a television appearance in early June, Michael W. Ferro Jr., the chairman of the newspaper and magazine publishing company Tronc — formerly known as Tribune Publishing — made an astonishing claim.

articles.headline: A Saudi Morals Enforcer Called for a More Liberal Islam. Then the Death Threats Began.
articles.snippet: A longtime morals enforcer began to question the rules. He told his story to a Times correspondent who spent weeks in Saudi Arabia trying to understand its hyper-conservative strain of Islam, which is often blamed for terrorism.
articles.abstract: A longtime morals enforcer began to question the rules. He told his story to a Times correspondent who spent weeks in Saudi Arabia trying to understand its hyper-conservative strain of Islam, which is often blamed for terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — For most of his adult life, Ahmed Qassim al-Ghamdi worked among the bearded enforcers of Saudi Arabia. He was a dedicated employee of the Commission for the Promotion of Virtue and the Prevention of Vice — known abroad as the religious police — serving with the front-line troops protecting the Islamic kingdom from Westernization, secularism and anything but the most conservative Islamic practices.

articles.headline: Texas Open-Carry Laws Blurred Lines Between Suspects and Marchers
articles.snippet: The mayor of Dallas suggests tightening the state’s gun laws to make it tougher to carry long arms in public.
articles.abstract: The mayor of Dallas suggests tightening the state’s gun laws to make it tougher to carry long arms in public.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — As a demonstration against police shootings made its way downtown here on Thursday, it differed from others around the country in one startling way: Twenty to 30 of the marchers showed up with AR-15s and other types of military-style rifles and wore them openly, with the straps slung across their shoulders and backs.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Alan Blinder and David Montgomery

articles.headline: U.F.C. Sells Itself for $4 Billion
articles.snippet: The talent giant WME-IMG is getting backing from private equity heavyweights to acquire the mixed martial arts league from the Fertitta brothers.
articles.abstract: The talent giant WME-IMG is getting backing from private equity heavyweights to acquire the mixed martial arts league from the Fertitta brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ultimate Fighting Championship seemed for years to be a curio, a niche sport for those interested in seeing combatants pummel one another in an octagonal cage.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Theresa May Is Poised to Be Britain’s Next Prime Minister
articles.snippet: Ms. May is set to take over on Wednesday, succeeding David Cameron at a time of immense upheaval for Britain.
articles.abstract: Ms. May is set to take over on Wednesday, succeeding David Cameron at a time of immense upheaval for Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Theresa May emerged on Monday as Britain’s next prime minister, becoming the second woman, after Margaret Thatcher, to hold that post. She faces multiple challenges as soon as she takes office, from negotiating the nation’s departure from the European Union to addressing deep social and political divisions to reviving a wounded economy.

articles.headline: Can We Ignore the Alarm Bells the Bond Market Is Ringing?
articles.snippet: Interest rates are ultralow across the globe. Here’s what that may be telling us about the economic future.
articles.abstract: Interest rates are ultralow across the globe. Here’s what that may be telling us about the economic future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial media tend to report breathlessly about what the stock market did yesterday. But savvy economic analysts have always known the bond market is the place to look for a real sense of where the economy is going, or at least where the smart money thinks it is going.

articles.headline: More Frequent Fliers Pay for a First-Class Upgrade That Once Was Free
articles.snippet: As airlines offer deals to entice passengers to move to first class, frequent fliers often either do without or pay for a perk they used to get free.
articles.abstract: As airlines offer deals to entice passengers to move to first class, frequent fliers often either do without or pay for a perk they used to get free.
articles.lead_paragraph: The perks of being a frequent flier are not as valuable as they once were. That is especially evident to travelers hoping to score a free upgrade to first class.
